elements.content: The self-assembly of ZnII, CdII, and CuII salts with the angular ligand 1,3,4-thiadiazole-2,5-di-3-pyridyl (L1 ) and three secondary ligands, 1,3-di-4-pyridylpropane (L2 ), 4,4′-dipyridyl (L3 ), and 2,3-dimethylpyrazine (L4 ), produced six new one- and two-dimensional coordination polymers. The unusual two-dimensional bilayer coordination polymer [Zn(L1 )(SO4)] n (1) obtained from L1 , L3 (or L4 ), and ZnSO4·7H2O has SO4 2−-bridged chiral inorganic 1-D ladders that are wound by L1 from two unparallel directions to form a novel chiral channel structure. According to the same synthetic procedure of 1, only the displacement of L3 (or L4 ) with L2 , however, afforded the one-dimensional coordination polymer {[Zn(L1 )2(H2O)(SO4)](H2O)2} n (2). Interestingly, the elegant dipyridyl ligands L2 , L3 , and L4 , unlike their analogue L1 coordinating to metal ions, affect the structural configuration of the resulting single crystals, even though they do not exist in these compounds. Another 2-D bilayer coordination polymer, [Cd(L1 )(H2O)(SO4)] n (3), synthesized from L1 and CdSO4·7H2O, however, has a different framework from 1. By contrast, the replacement of a bridging SO4 2− anion in 3 by a SCN− anion results in a 2-D monolayer coordination polymer [Cd2(L1 )3(SCN)4] n (4) with the grid network. Furthermore, the 1-D zigzig coordination polymer [Cu2(L1 )(μ-OAc)4] n (5) and the 2-D coordination polymer {[Cu(L3 )2(H2O)2](L1 )(H2O)2(PF6)2} n (6) were organized by a similar procedure, with the main difference of the secondary ligand L3 being used only in the synthesis of 6. The structural diversity of the six coordination polymers perhaps mainly results from the changes of secondary ligands and bridging anions, showing that the two factors play important roles in the construction of various metal−organic frameworks.

elements.content: The influence of analogue dipyridyl ligands and bridging anions on structural diversity in six coordination polymers with the angular dipyridyl ligand 1,3,4-thiadiazole-2,5-di-3-pyridyl has been systematically investigated. Especially, we have found that secondary ligands can display interesting influence on the frameworks of MOFs even though they are noncoordinating and do not exist in MOF compounds.

Especially, we have found that secondary ligands can display interesting influence on the frameworks of MOFs even though they are noncoordinating and do not exist in MOF compounds.

elements.content: The design and construction of novel coordination polymers are very important parts of crystal engineering not only for specially functional material purpose but also for their fascinating structures. So far, the design and synthesis of new ligands with various coordinating modes, the exploration of synthetic methods to construct coordination polymers, and investigation on the effect of various factors upon architectures have greatly contributed to this field. Especially, a good understanding of the influential laws of many parameters involved in the formation of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) can help to more accurately predict and more rationally design MOFs so as to successfully synthesize desired materials. Among many influential factors, organic spacers with changeable bridging length, conformation, and flexibility are very important in the construction and structural tuning of MOFs. The change of ligand or the use of a novel ligand can lead to the formation of new coordination polymers if a monoligand is used in the crystal engineering, but a mixed-ligand system consisting of two or three types provides more variability to construct much more complicated and fantastic topologies. For example, in the two-ligand MOF assembly systems, the secondary ligands including organic and inorganic can manipulate the structural topologies in either the terminal or the bridging coordination modes. Fedorov et al. adopted unusual anionic rhenium-chalcogenide-cyano clusters as bridges to tune the chiral crystal structure. Wang and co-workers used two pyridyl ligands as terminals in 1-D zigzag chains to tune the supramolecular structures from a net-to-net network to a 2-fold interpenetrated framework. Cao and his co-researchers changed the secondary ligands from terminal ligands to bridging ligands to manipulate the synthesis of helical structures. However, due to the complexity and difficult prediction of the resulting composition or structure, the influential laws in a multiple ligand system are still less understood and not conclusive. Therefore, much more corresponding work is required to be done and a deliberately rational design would be a long-range challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and construction of novel coordination polymers are very important parts of crystal engineering not only for specially functional material purpose but also for their fascinating structures. So far, the design and synthesis of new ligands with various coordinating modes, the exploration of synthetic methods to construct coordination polymers, and investigation on the effect of various factors upon architectures have greatly contributed to this field. Especially, a good understanding of the influential laws of many parameters involved in the formation of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) can help to more accurately predict and more rationally design MOFs so as to successfully synthesize desired materials. Among many influential factors, organic spacers with changeable bridging length, conformation, and flexibility are very important in the construction and structural tuning of MOFs. The change of ligand or the use of a novel ligand can lead to the formation of new coordination polymers if a monoligand is used in the crystal engineering, but a mixed-ligand system consisting of two or three types provides more variability to construct much more complicated and fantastic topologies. For example, in the two-ligand MOF assembly systems, the secondary ligands including organic and inorganic can manipulate the structural topologies in either the terminal or the bridging coordination modes. Fedorov et al. adopted unusual anionic rhenium-chalcogenide-cyano clusters as bridges to tune the chiral crystal structure. Wang and co-workers used two pyridyl ligands as terminals in 1-D zigzag chains to tune the supramolecular structures from a net-to-net network to a 2-fold interpenetrated framework. Cao and his co-researchers changed the secondary ligands from terminal ligands to bridging ligands to manipulate the synthesis of helical structures. However, due to the complexity and difficult prediction of the resulting composition or structure, the influential laws in a multiple ligand system are still less understood and not conclusive. Therefore, much more corresponding work is required to be done and a deliberately rational design would be a long-range challenge.

elements.content: Our studies on the effects of secondary ligands on structural topologies of MOFs were based on four analogue ligands, 1,3,4-thiadiazole-2,5-di-3-pyridyl (L1 ), 1,3-di-4-pyridylpropane (L2 ), 4,4′-dipyridyl (L3 ), and 2,3-dimethylpyrazine (L4 ). Although the four ligands all can bridge metal ions by nitrogen atoms of the pyridyl rings, their space directions, flexibilities, and separation lengths are different (Scheme ). L1 , similar to other thiadiazole bridging ligands, is an angular ligand with a rigid spacer thiadiazole ring, while ligands L2 , L3 , and L4 , widely studied in the literature, are graceful linear or nearly linear bridges in the construction of MOFs.7c, In comparison with very rigid bridges L3 and L4 , L2 derived from L3 is a very flexible bridging ligand due to its three methylene groups between two 4-pyridyl rings. Thus the combination of L1 (supposed as a main ligand) with L2 , L3 , and L4 (secondary ligands) in the self-assembly process produced somewhat two-ligand-coordinating systems. Additionally, SCN− anions, which can act as bridging ligands, were used to displace SO4 2− anions in the study of the influence of anionic ligands.

Although the four ligands all can bridge metal ions by nitrogen atoms of the pyridyl rings, their space directions, flexibilities, and separation lengths are different (Scheme ). L1 , similar to other thiadiazole bridging ligands, is an angular ligand with a rigid spacer thiadiazole ring,  while ligands L2 , L3 , and L4 , widely studied in the literature, are graceful linear or nearly linear bridges in the construction of MOFs.7c,  In comparison with very rigid bridges L3  and L4 , L2  derived from L3  is a very flexible bridging ligand due to its three methylene groups between two 4-pyridyl rings. Additionally, SCN- anions, which can act as bridging ligands, were used to displace SO4 2- anions in the study of the influence of anionic ligands.

In this research, four two-dimensional coordination polymers, [Zn(L1 )(SO4)] n (1), [Cd(L1 )(H2O)(SO4)] n (3), [Cd2(L1 )3(SCN)4] n (4), and {[Cu(L3 )2(H2O)2](L1 )(H2O)2(PF6)2} n (6), and two one-dimensional coordination polymers, {[Zn(L1 )2(H2O)(SO4)](H2O)2} n (2) and [Cu2(L1 )(μ-OAc)4] n (5) (Scheme ), were obtained as their single crystals. The details of their syntheses and structures show the effects of ligands and coordinating anions on conformations of frameworks. Especially, we unexpectedly found that secondary ligands L2 , L3 , and L4 display interesting influences even though they do not coordinate or exist in the resulting compounds 1 and 2.

The details of their syntheses and structures show the effects of ligands and coordinating anions on conformations of frameworks. Especially, we unexpectedly found that secondary ligands L2 , L3 , and L4  display interesting influences even though they do not coordinate or exist in the resulting compounds 1 and 2.

All reagents and solvents were commercially available except for L1 , which was synthesized according to the literature and a modified method (conventional heating to 170 °C for 6 h in our experiments instead of microwave heating to 150 °C for 1 h in the literature). Infrared spectra were recorded on a FTS-40 infrared spectrometer as KBr pellets. Elemental analyses were performed on a Flash EA 1112 analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed under an argon atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min on a Netzsch STA409 PC instrument, in the temperature range 25–900 °C. UV–visible spectra were recorded on a PGENERAL TU-1800SPC spectrophotometer. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AMX-400 FT-NMR spectrometer. Fluorescent properties were determined by a Horiba Jobin Yvon FluoroMax-P spectrofluorometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reagents and solvents were commercially available except for L1 , which was synthesized according to the literature and a modified method (conventional heating to 170 °C for 6 h in our experiments instead of microwave heating to 150 °C for 1 h in the literature). Infrared spectra were recorded on a FTS-40 infrared spectrometer as KBr pellets. Elemental analyses were performed on a Flash EA 1112 analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed under an argon atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min on a Netzsch STA409 PC instrument, in the temperature range 25-900 °C. UV-visible spectra were recorded on a PGENERAL TU-1800SPC spectrophotometer. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AMX-400 FT-NMR spectrometer. Fluorescent properties were determined by a Horiba Jobin Yvon FluoroMax-P spectrofluorometer.

elements.content: To a solution of L1 (0.024 g, 0.1 mmol) and L3 (0.016 g, 0.1 mmol) (or L4 , 0.011 g, 0.1 mmol) in the mixed solvent (5 mL of chloroform, 10 mL of methanol) was added ZnSO4·7H2O (0.029 g, 0.1 mmol) in methanol (15 mL). The mixture was stirred for 20 min and then filtered. The filtrate was allowed to slowly evaporate the solvents at room temperature, and about 40 days later single crystals (colorless block) suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained. Yield: 15% (based on ZnSO4·7H2O). Anal. Calcd (found) for C12H8N4O4S2Zn: C, 35.88 (35.33); H, 2.01 (2.16); N, 13.95 (13.39). elements.content:
Perchlorate salts and perchlorate metal complexes of organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only small amounts of materials should be prepared, and these should be handled with great caution.

X-ray Diffraction Studies

X-ray diffraction data for single crystals were collected at 291 K on a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal and incident beam monochromator using Mo Kα radiaton (λ = 0.71073 Å). Crystal data, data collection parameters, and analysis statistics for 1–6 are listed in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Tables −4. The frames were integrated in the Siemens SAINTPLUS software package, and the data were corrected for absorption using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by the direct method (SHELXS 97) and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were inserted at the calculated positions and allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms. The hydrogen atoms attached to oxygen atoms were not located.
elements.clean_text:
Safety Note

Perchlorate salts and perchlorate metal complexes of organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only small amounts of materials should be prepared, and these should be handled with great caution.

X-ray Diffraction Studies

X-ray diffraction data for single crystals were collected at 291 K on a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal and incident beam monochromator using Mo Kα radiaton (λ = 0.71073 Å). Crystal data, data collection parameters, and analysis statistics for 1-6 are listed in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Tables -4. The frames were integrated in the Siemens SAINTPLUS software package, and the data were corrected for absorption using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by the direct method (SHELXS 97) and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were inserted at the calculated positions and allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms. The hydrogen atoms attached to oxygen atoms were not located.

elements.content: Due to the poor solubility of L1 in methanol at room temperature, a mixed solvent of CH3OH/CHCl3 was used to increase its solubility. Mixing Cu(OAc)2·H2O with L1 in methanol led to a precipitate, whereas no precipitate when L1 was replaced by a mixture of L1 and L3 . So a two-layer diffusion method was used to form the single crystals of 5 by L1 and Cu(OAc)2·H2O, while a solvent evaporation method was suitable for the crystallization of 6.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and General Characterization

Due to the poor solubility of L1  in methanol at room temperature, a mixed solvent of CH3OH/CHCl3 was used to increase its solubility. Mixing Cu(OAc)2⋅H2O with L1  in methanol led to a precipitate, whereas no precipitate when L1  was replaced by a mixture of L1  and L3 . So a two-layer diffusion method was used to form the single crystals of 5 by L1  and Cu(OAc)2⋅H2O, while a solvent evaporation method was suitable for the crystallization of 6.

elements.content: All complexes were characterized by elemental analyses and IR spectroscopy. Thermal stabilities of complexes 1, 4, and 5 were also measured. In the IR spectra of 1, 2, and 3, there are characteristic bands of the SO4 2− anions at 1040–1120 cm−1, indicating their bidentate or tridentate coordination feature. For 5, the characteristic bands of bridging CH3COO− anions were found at 1620, 1435, and 704 cm−1. The IR spectrum of 4 shows a very strong absorption band of SCN− anions at 2106 cm−1. For 6, the characteristic band of PF6 − anions was located at 844 cm−1. The thermally stable temperatures of metal–ligand skeletons in 1, 4, and 5 are higher than 200 °C (TG curves of 1, 4, and 5 shown in −S3). XPRD spectra of 4 and 5 determined by experiment are in line with the simulated ones of single crystals, which shows the same components and structures of bulk powder samples as those of their single crystals (Figures S4 and S5).

For 5, the characteristic bands of bridging CH3COO- anions were found at 1620, 1435, and 704 cm-1. The IR spectrum of 4 shows a very strong absorption band of SCN- anions at 2106 cm-1. For 6, the characteristic band of PF6 - anions was located at 844 cm-1. The thermally stable temperatures of metal-ligand skeletons in 1, 4, and 5 are higher than 200 °C (TG curves of 1, 4, and 5 shown in -S3). XPRD spectra of 4 and 5 determined by experiment are in line with the simulated ones of single crystals, which shows the same components and structures of bulk powder samples as those of their single crystals (Figures S4 and S5).

elements.content: This compound crystallizes in the space group P21/c and is constructed as a 2-D double-layered coordination polymer. The central zinc ion is in a distorted square-pyramidal coordination environment in which two oxygen atoms of two distinct sulfate anions and two nitrogen atoms of two distinct L1 ligands are located in the equatorial positions and one oxygen atom of one sulfate anion is located in the apical position (Figure a). In compound 1 sulfate anions acting as three-connectors bind metal nodes together to create ladder-like inorganic 1-D chains of ZnSO4. The sulfate anions bridge ZnII ions through two oxygen atoms [O(1), O(4)] to form two zigzag −Zn−O−S−O−Zn− chains as rims, which are hinged together by rungs [O(3)]. Surprisingly, the ladder-like inorganic 1-D chain also contains a right-hand helix bridged by oxygen atoms [O(1), O(3)] of sulfate anions with a 2-fold screw axis passing through along the b axis (Figure b). The Zn···Zn distances bridged by sulfate anions are about ca. 4.921 and ca. 6.546 Å, respectively, and the latter is also the pitch of the helix. Finally, those chiral ladder-like inorganic 1-D chains of ZnSO4 are wound by L1 molecules from two different directions to form a two-dimensional double-layered structure (Figure c).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures. [Zn(L1 )(SO4)] n , 1 

This compound crystallizes in the space group P21/c and is constructed as a 2-D double-layered coordination polymer. The central zinc ion is in a distorted square-pyramidal coordination environment in which two oxygen atoms of two distinct sulfate anions and two nitrogen atoms of two distinct L1  ligands are located in the equatorial positions and one oxygen atom of one sulfate anion is located in the apical position (Figure a). In compound 1 sulfate anions acting as three-connectors bind metal nodes together to create ladder-like inorganic 1-D chains of ZnSO4. The sulfate anions bridge ZnII ions through two oxygen atoms [O(1), O(4)] to form two zigzag -Zn-O-S-O-Zn- chains as rims, which are hinged together by rungs [O(3)]. Surprisingly, the ladder-like inorganic 1-D chain also contains a right-hand helix bridged by oxygen atoms [O(1), O(3)] of sulfate anions with a 2-fold screw axis passing through along the b axis (Figure b). The Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances bridged by sulfate anions are about ca. 4.921 and ca. 6.546 Å, respectively, and the latter is also the pitch of the helix. Finally, those chiral ladder-like inorganic 1-D chains of ZnSO4 are wound by L1  molecules from two different directions to form a two-dimensional double-layered structure (Figure c).

(b) Cylindrical view of the right-hand ZnSO4 helical chain. (c) Topology diagram showing the structures of double layers and ladder-like 1-D ZnSO4 chains. (d) Diagram showing a right-hand triple helix. (e) Packing diagram showing the square tunnels.

elements.content: More impressive structural character of this compound is that there is another homochiral triple helix organized by L1 and ZnSO4 from which chiral channels are constructed along the crystallographic b axis. As shown in Figure d, sulfate anions and L1 molecules in an anticoordination mode bridge zinc ions to form one infinite right-hand −Zn−L1 −Zn−O−S−O−Zn− helix. The distances of two zinc ions bridged by one L1 molecule and one sulfate anion are about ca. 12.362 and ca. 4.921 Å, respectively, and the pitch of the helix is about ca. 19.638 Å. Just moving forward one-third pitch in turn, there are another two helices wrapping along the same axis, and thereby the distances between neighboring helices are equal. Moreover, the three helices are linked together by other coordinating oxygen atoms of sulfate anions to form chiral square channels (ca. 12 × 4 Å2), which are further connected by the chiral inorganic 1-D chains into an unusual chiral 2-D layer (Figure e). The reason that this compound crystallizes in the achiral space group may be the lack of appropriate intermolecular interactions for chiral discrimination between neighboring chiral 2-D layers, and the adjacent layers are related by inversion centers and the whole crystal is racemic.

elements.content: The structure of compound 2 consists of 1-D neutral Zn−O−S−O−Zn−O−S−O− zigzig chains where sulfate anions act as μ-2 connectors by two oxygen atoms bridging two zinc ions. From two opposite sides of the 1-D chain, two L1 molecules are bound to each zinc center only using their one-side pyridyl nitrogen atoms. The dipyridyl ligand L1 displays an unusual monodentate coordination mode, which is different from the bridging mode in compounds 1, 3, and 5 and the complexes of its dipyridyl analogues (Figure ). One oxygen atom of one water molecule, two oxygen atoms of two distinct sulfate anions, and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of two distinct L1 molecules define a distorted square-pyramidal coordination environment around the zinc center. Two oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms are in the equatorial positions, and one oxygen atom is in the apical position.
elements.clean_text:
{[Zn(L1 )2(H2O)(SO4)](H2O)2} n , 2 

The structure of compound 2 consists of 1-D neutral Zn-O-S-O-Zn-O-S-O- zigzig chains where sulfate anions act as μ-2 connectors by two oxygen atoms bridging two zinc ions. From two opposite sides of the 1-D chain, two L1  molecules are bound to each zinc center only using their one-side pyridyl nitrogen atoms. The dipyridyl ligand L1  displays an unusual monodentate coordination mode, which is different from the bridging mode in compounds 1, 3, and 5 and the complexes of its dipyridyl analogues (Figure ). One oxygen atom of one water molecule, two oxygen atoms of two distinct sulfate anions, and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of two distinct L1  molecules define a distorted square-pyramidal coordination environment around the zinc center. Two oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms are in the equatorial positions, and one oxygen atom is in the apical position.

elements.content: It is interesting that the L1 molecules on the two opposite sides of the 1-D chain bend to the center and the whole structure of one 1-D chain is mirror symmetric. The symmetric mirror plane is defined by three coordinating oxygen atoms, one central zinc atom, and one sulfur atom ().

The symmetric mirror plane is defined by three coordinating oxygen atoms, one central zinc atom, and one sulfur atom ().

elements.content: The conditions to synthesize compounds 1 and 2 are almost the same except for only one difference of secondary ligands, which are L3 (or L4 ) and L2 , respectively. The X-ray crystal structure analyses of compounds 1 and 2 show that although the secondary ligands did not coordinate to the metal ions and also were not the components of the complexes, they do affect the construction and structural diversity of coordination polymers. Similarly the tuning type of coexistent anions was reported by Kitagawa and his co-workers. Perhaps the different structural motifs of 1 and 2 directly come from the changes of bridging modes of the sulfate anions in the different coordinating environments, though no further evidence can be given by far. Sulfate anions in complex 2 have a μ-2 bridging mode, but in complex 1 they have a μ-3 bridging mode. This is caused by the changes of secondary ligands from L3 (or L4 ) to L2 . The influential mechanism of L2 , L3 , and L4 may be that the presence of the secondary ligands changes the coordinating environments of L1 molecules or sulfate anions in solutions by hydrogen bondings or other weak noncovalent interactions. The coordinating environments in the formation of compound 1 in the presence of L3 and L4 are almost the same because L3 and L4 have the same rigid structures, which are different from the flexible one of L2 . On the other hand, strong covalent bonds predominating in solid compounds cause the exclusion of the secondary ligands from solid crystals, while they are formed from solution. The same type of influence of the solvent or coexistent anion on the structure probably has the same mechanism.

The X-ray crystal structure analyses of compounds 1 and 2 show that although the secondary ligands did not coordinate to the metal ions and also were not the components of the complexes, they do affect the construction and structural diversity of coordination polymers. Similarly the tuning type of coexistent anions was reported by Kitagawa and his co-workers. Perhaps the different structural motifs of 1 and 2 directly come from the changes of bridging modes of the sulfate anions in the different coordinating environments, though no further evidence can be given by far. Sulfate anions in complex 2 have a μ-2 bridging mode, but in complex 1 they have a μ-3 bridging mode. This is caused by the changes of secondary ligands from L3  (or L4 ) to L2 . The influential mechanism of L2 , L3 , and L4  may be that the presence of the secondary ligands changes the coordinating environments of L1  molecules or sulfate anions in solutions by hydrogen bondings or other weak noncovalent interactions. The coordinating environments in the formation of compound 1 in the presence of L3  and L4  are almost the same because L3  and L4  have the same rigid structures, which are different from the flexible one of L2 . On the other hand, strong covalent bonds predominating in solid compounds cause the exclusion of the secondary ligands from solid crystals, while they are formed from solution. The same type of influence of the solvent or coexistent anion on the structure probably has the same mechanism.

elements.content: This compound crystallizes in the space group P1̅ and is constructed into a 2-D double-layered coordination polymer. The central cadmium ion is in a distorted octahedral coordination environment in which one aqua oxygen atom and three oxygen atoms of three distinct sulfate anions are located in the equatorial plane and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of two distinct L1 ligands are in polar positions (Figure a). In compound 3 sulfate anions also acting as three-connectors bind metal nodes to create ladder-like inorganic 1-D chains of CdSO4, with sulfate anions bridging CdII ions through two oxygen atoms [O(1), O(3)] to form two zigzag −Cd−O−S−O−Cd− chains as rims that are hinged together by rungs [O(2)]. Furthermore, those ladder-like inorganic 1-D chains are wound by parallel L1 molecules to form a 2-D double-layered structure (Figure b). The distances of the two planes defined by two layers and two adjacent inorganic ladders are about ca. 3.4 and ca. 8.3 Å, respectively. Attributed to antiparallel character of L1 molecules, the thiadiazole rings bending toward the inside of the double layers overlap with the pyridyl rings. Unlike compound 1, there are no fairly large channels between the two layers in 3. However the large bending angle (ca. 116°) between the coordinating direction of Cd−N and the extending direction of the ligand molecule makes the 2-D layers bend with the same angle to form wavy planes (Figure c). The lack of inorganic helix and chiral channels in compound 3 is mainly due to the lack of the cooperation of the distorted L1 molecules in the two layers.

elements.content: This compound also crystallizes in the space group P1̅ and is constructed into a 2-D layer coordination polymer. There are two different coordination environments of Cd ions caused by two different coordinating modes of L1 , though both types of CdII ions are six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms and two sulfur atoms of four distinct NCS− anions, as well as two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of two distinct L1 ligands. The Cd(1) ion is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from two distinct monodentate L1 molecules, while the Cd(2) ion is coordinated to those from bridging L1 molecules. Either the metal center Cd(1) or Cd(2) has an elongated octahedral coordination geometry with two longer Cd−S bonds along the axial directions and four shorter Cd−N bonds located in the equatorial plane.
elements.clean_text:
[Cd2(L1)3(SCN)4] n , 4 

This compound also crystallizes in the space group P1̅ and is constructed into a 2-D layer coordination polymer. There are two different coordination environments of Cd ions caused by two different coordinating modes of L1 , though both types of CdII ions are six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms and two sulfur atoms of four distinct NCS- anions, as well as two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of two distinct L1  ligands. The Cd(1) ion is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from two distinct monodentate L1  molecules, while the Cd(2) ion is coordinated to those from bridging L1  molecules. Either the metal center Cd(1) or Cd(2) has an elongated octahedral coordination geometry with two longer Cd-S bonds along the axial directions and four shorter Cd-N bonds located in the equatorial plane.

elements.content: The 2-D layer framework of compound 4 is constructed by connecting 1-D metal−anion chains together through L1 −Cd−L1 −Cd chains. Two bridging NCS− groups link two adjacent CdII centers to form a 1-D double chain with the (2,4) topology along the ab plane with the distance of two adjacent CdII ions ca. 5.826 Å. Furthermore, each L1 molecule connects two cadmium atoms from neighboring chains with the L1 -separated Cd···Cd distance of ca. 13.5 Å. The angular geometry of bridging L1 , together with its cis arrangement mode around the Cd(2) center, results in parallel L1 −Cd−L1 −Cd wavy chains. By these metal−organic chains, the parallel 1-D [Cd2(μ-NCS-N,S)2] n chains are bound together to generate a 2-D layer containing square grids in the bc plane with dimensions of ca. 13 × 12 Å2. Each grid filled with two monodentate L1 molecules as guests has a (4, 6) topology that contains six CdII ions (four among them are connecting nodes), two L1 molecules, and eight NCS− groups (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The 2-D layer framework of compound 4 is constructed by connecting 1-D metal-anion chains together through L1 -Cd-L1 -Cd chains. Two bridging NCS- groups link two adjacent CdII centers to form a 1-D double chain with the (2,4) topology along the ab plane with the distance of two adjacent CdII ions ca. 5.826 Å. Furthermore, each L1  molecule connects two cadmium atoms from neighboring chains with the L1 -separated Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance of ca. 13.5 Å. The angular geometry of bridging L1 , together with its cis arrangement mode around the Cd(2) center, results in parallel L1 -Cd-L1 -Cd wavy chains. By these metal-organic chains, the parallel 1-D [Cd2(μ-NCS-N,S)2] n  chains are bound together to generate a 2-D layer containing square grids in the bc plane with dimensions of ca. 13 × 12 Å2. Each grid filled with two monodentate L1  molecules as guests has a (4, 6) topology that contains six CdII ions (four among them are connecting nodes), two L1  molecules, and eight NCS- groups (Figure ).

elements.content: For 3 and 4, anions acting as bridging ligands also affect the conformation of coordination polymers. There are many examples of 1-D coordination polymers such as 2 or 1-D inorganic chains where the SO4 2− anions act as μ2 bridges, as well as a large amount of 2-D and 3-D motifs reorganized by μ3-SO4 2− or μ4-SO4 2− spacers, which can extend in multiple directions. However, the ladder-like inorganic MSO4 (M = Cd, Zn) 1-D chains connected by μ3-SO4 2− modes in 1 and 3 have not been reported to our knowledge. Based on those CdSO4 ladders in 3 whose two edges were connected by L1 , a 2-D bilayer framework was formed. Unlike SO4 2− anions, NCS− anions sometimes act as terminal groups and sometimes as bridges to form linear structures with metal ions. So for 4, a 2-D monolayer structure was constructed by linear inorganic Cd−(NCS)2−Cd chains being further linked through L1 .
elements.clean_text: For 3 and 4, anions acting as bridging ligands also affect the conformation of coordination polymers. There are many examples of 1-D coordination polymers such as 2 or 1-D inorganic chains where the SO4 2- anions act as μ2 bridges, as well as a large amount of 2-D and 3-D motifs reorganized by μ3-SO4 2- or μ4-SO4 2- spacers, which can extend in multiple directions. However, the ladder-like inorganic MSO4 (M = Cd, Zn) 1-D chains connected by μ3-SO4 2- modes in 1 and 3 have not been reported to our knowledge. Based on those CdSO4 ladders in 3 whose two edges were connected by L1 , a 2-D bilayer framework was formed. Unlike SO4 2- anions, NCS- anions sometimes act as terminal groups and sometimes as bridges to form linear structures with metal ions. So for 4, a 2-D monolayer structure was constructed by linear inorganic Cd-(NCS)2-Cd chains being further linked through L1 .

elements.content: The crystal structure of compound 5, which crystalized in the space group P1̅ consists of a zigzig 1-D neutral chain, −Cu−(μ-OAc)4−Cu−L1 −. The Cu ion is pentacoordinated to four oxygen atoms of four distinct acetate anions and one nitrogen atom from the pyridyl ring of L1 to form a square-pyramid geometry. The CuII center deviates from the mean equatorial plane defined by four coordinated oxygen atoms toward the apical nitrogen atom by ca. 0.198 Å. The bond lengths and angles (see Table ) are similar to those in its analogues. Two adjacent CuII centers are tightly bridged by four acetate anions in syn−syn fashion to form a binuclear subunit, in which the Cu···Cu distance is very short (2.6257(6) Å) (Figure ). These subunits are further linked by bridges L1 in a trans arrangement to construct the 1-D chain, with the neighboring Cu···Cu separation of ca. 13.14 Å. Two pyridyl rings within each L1 molecule are parallel, which is different from that of compounds 1 and 2. The dihedral angle between the thiadiazole and the pyridyl ring is ca. 21.6°. The direction of pyridyl nitrogen atoms coordinating to CuII ions of inorganic units is not in accordance with the extending direction of the L1 molecule, with the angle of ca. 121.2° between the line through two nitrogen atoms connected by one inorganic unit and the line defined by two C(5) atoms of one L1 molecule. So the 1-D organic–inorganic chain is deformed into a zigzag conformation.

elements.content: In complex 6, there is a 2-D (4,4) sheet constructed by L3 molecules and CuII ions, which was reported in the literature. One CuII center is coordinated to four nitrogen atoms from four distinct bridging ligand L3 molecules and two oxygen atoms from two distinct water molecules to form an octahedral conformation (). But noncoordinating L1 molecules anchored in the framework make the whole supramolecular network change a lot. Each L1 molecule as guest interpenetrates along the b axis (deviation angle from b axis is ca. 43.53°) into one square grid with the dimensions ca. 11 × 11 Å2 and angular angles of ca. 84.12°. Each square grid is constructed by four CuII ions bridged by four L3 molecules (Figure ). The minimum intramolecular distance of two CuII ions is ca. 11.16 Å.

But noncoordinating L1  molecules anchored in the framework make the whole supramolecular network change a lot. Each L1  molecule as guest interpenetrates along the b axis (deviation angle from b axis is ca. 43.53°) into one square grid with the dimensions ca. 11 × 11 Å2 and angular angles of ca. 84.12°. Each square grid is constructed by four CuII ions bridged by four L3  molecules (Figure ). The minimum intramolecular distance of two CuII ions is ca. 11.16 Å.

elements.content: Comparatively, the presence of L3 in 6 causes L1 not to act as a bridging spacer as that in 5, but just as guest molecules hosted in nets. It is obvious that L3 tends to have the stronger coordinating abilities with metal ions in the current self-assembly environment than L1 . So the presence of L3 changes the coordinating role of L1 ; therefore the metal−organic framework of 6 is very different from that of 5.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of compounds 5 and 6 have been investigated over the temperature range 5–300 K at 0.1 T. The χM and χM T vs T plots of 5 and 6 are shown in and S9, respectively. For 5, a plat maximun of χM at 280–300 K (0.0013 cm3 mol−1) indicates a very strong antiferromagnetic coupling. There is a clear increase of the χM values when the temperature is less than 20 K, indicating a trace amount of monomeric CuII impurities with paramagnetic magnetic properties. The susceptibility data can be simulated with the equation (see ESI) reported by Dalai et al. The best-fit parameters are J = −333.2 cm−1, g = 2.03, ρ = 0.0007, and an agreement factor R = 1.5 × 10−7. For 6, the χM value increases from 0.0034 cm3 mol−1 at 300 K to 0.19 cm3 mol−1 at 5 K as the temperature decreases. The χM T value continuously increases and reaches a maximum of 1.09 cm3 mol−1 K at 15 K upon cooling. This behavior indicates a ferromagnetic interaction. Below 15 K, the χM T value decreases rapidly, which may be due to the intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions and zero-field splitting (ZFS). The susceptibility data can be simulated with the equation (see ESI) reported by Chou et al. The best fit for χM T leads to g = 2.02, J = 4.64 cm−1, D = 2.55 cm−1, |TIP| = 0.00008 cm3 mol−1, and R = 6.38 × 10−6. The small positive value of J indicates that the ferromagnetic interactions between two long-range neighboring copper(II) ions are very weak.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties of 5 and 6 

The magnetic properties of compounds 5 and 6 have been investigated over the temperature range 5-300 K at 0.1 T. The χM and χM T vs T plots of 5 and 6 are shown in  and S9, respectively. For 5, a plat maximun of χM at 280-300 K (0.0013 cm3 mol-1) indicates a very strong antiferromagnetic coupling. There is a clear increase of the χM values when the temperature is less than 20 K, indicating a trace amount of monomeric CuII impurities with paramagnetic magnetic properties. The susceptibility data can be simulated with the equation (see ESI) reported by Dalai et al. The best-fit parameters are J = -333.2 cm-1, g = 2.03, ρ = 0.0007, and an agreement factor R = 1.5 × 10-7. For 6, the χM value increases from 0.0034 cm3 mol-1 at 300 K to 0.19 cm3 mol-1 at 5 K as the temperature decreases. The χM T value continuously increases and reaches a maximum of 1.09 cm3 mol-1 K at 15 K upon cooling. This behavior indicates a ferromagnetic interaction. Below 15 K, the χM T value decreases rapidly, which may be due to the intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions and zero-field splitting (ZFS). The susceptibility data can be simulated with the equation (see ESI) reported by Chou et al. The best fit for χM T leads to g = 2.02, J = 4.64 cm-1, D = 2.55 cm-1, |TIP| = 0.00008 cm3 mol-1, and R = 6.38 × 10-6. The small positive value of J indicates that the ferromagnetic interactions between two long-range neighboring copper(II) ions are very weak.

elements.content: Emission measurements at room temperature show that complex 4 exhibits fluorescence at 410 nm in the solid state upon excitation at 355 nm (Figure S10). In the same excitation, the emission maximum of L1 can be found at 416 nm. The emission band of 4 is mainly due to an intraligand emission state as reported for CdII or other d10 metal complexes with N-donor ligands. This indicates that the coordination polymers of L1 with d10 metals can be utilized as potential luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Property of 4 

Emission measurements at room temperature show that complex 4 exhibits fluorescence at 410 nm in the solid state upon excitation at 355 nm (Figure S10). In the same excitation, the emission maximum of L1  can be found at 416 nm. The emission band of 4 is mainly due to an intraligand emission state as reported for CdII or other d10 metal complexes with N-donor ligands. This indicates that the coordination polymers of L1  with d10 metals can be utilized as potential luminescent materials.

elements.content: We have systematically synthesized and structurally characterized six new coordination polymers from one angular bipyrdyl ligand and three usual bipyridyl or pyrazine ligands with three transitional metal salts. The structural diversity of two ZnII and two CuII complexes affected by the secondary ligand and two CdII complexes by the change of bridging inorganic anions have been discussed. The mechanism of ligand effects needs to be further studied and no doubt will contribute to crystal engineering.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have systematically synthesized and structurally characterized six new coordination polymers from one angular bipyrdyl ligand and three usual bipyridyl or pyrazine ligands with three transitional metal salts. The structural diversity of two ZnII and two CuII complexes affected by the secondary ligand and two CdII complexes by the change of bridging inorganic anions have been discussed. The mechanism of ligand effects needs to be further studied and no doubt will contribute to crystal engineering.

IR νKBr (cm-1): 3422 m, 3119 w, 1614 s, 1551 s, 1492 w, 1418 s, 1325 w, 1224 w, 1074 w, 1020 w, 844 vs, 816 s, 734 w, 682 w, 645 w, 620 w, 559 m, 512 w.

cln_elements.content:
The 2-D layer framework of compound 4 is constructed by connecting 1-D metal−anion chains together through L1 −Cd−L1 −Cd chains. Two bridging NCS− groups link two adjacent CdII centers to form a 1-D double chain with the (2,4) topology along the ab plane with the distance of two adjacent CdII ions ca. 5.826 Å. Furthermore, each L1 molecule connects two cadmium atoms from neighboring chains with the L1 -separated Cd···Cd distance of ca. 13.5 Å. The angular geometry of bridging L1 , together with its cis arrangement mode around the Cd(2) center, results in parallel L1 −Cd−L1 −Cd wavy chains. By these metal−organic chains, the parallel 1-D [Cd2(μ-NCS-N,S)2] n chains are bound together to generate a 2-D layer containing square grids in the bc plane with dimensions of ca. 13 × 12 Å2. Each grid filled with two monodentate L1 molecules as guests has a (4, 6) topology that contains six CdII ions (four among them are connecting nodes), two L1 molecules, and eight NCS− groups (Figure ).

Magnetic Properties of <bold>5</bold> and <bold>6</bold>

The magnetic properties of compounds 5 and 6 have been investigated over the temperature range 5–300 K at 0.1 T. The χM and χM T vs T plots of 5 and 6 are shown in and S9, respectively. For 5, a plat maximun of χM at 280–300 K (0.0013 cm3 mol−1) indicates a very strong antiferromagnetic coupling. There is a clear increase of the χM values when the temperature is less than 20 K, indicating a trace amount of monomeric CuII impurities with paramagnetic magnetic properties. The susceptibility data can be simulated with the equation (see ESI) reported by Dalai et al. The best-fit parameters are J = −333.2 cm−1, g = 2.03, ρ = 0.0007, and an agreement factor R = 1.5 × 10−7. For 6, the χM value increases from 0.0034 cm3 mol−1 at 300 K to 0.19 cm3 mol−1 at 5 K as the temperature decreases. The χM T value continuously increases and reaches a maximum of 1.09 cm3 mol−1 K at 15 K upon cooling. This behavior indicates a ferromagnetic interaction. Below 15 K, the χM T value decreases rapidly, which may be due to the intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions and zero-field splitting (ZFS). The susceptibility data can be simulated with the equation (see ESI) reported by Chou et al. The best fit for χM T leads to g = 2.02, J = 4.64 cm−1, D = 2.55 cm−1, |TIP| = 0.00008 cm3 mol−1, and R = 6.38 × 10−6. The small positive value of J indicates that the ferromagnetic interactions between two long-range neighboring copper(II) ions are very weak.

Fluorescent Property of <bold>4</bold>

Emission measurements at room temperature show that complex 4 exhibits fluorescence at 410 nm in the solid state upon excitation at 355 nm (Figure S10). In the same excitation, the emission maximum of L1 can be found at 416 nm. The emission band of 4 is mainly due to an intraligand emission state as reported for CdII or other d10 metal complexes with N-donor ligands. This indicates that the coordination polymers of L1 with d10 metals can be utilized as potential luminescent materials.
